Mahmoud Ahmadi-Nejad, a conservative hardliner, was recently elected president of Iran by a wide margin (around 60% IIRC). 
 
 This means thatt he conservatives are now running everthing in Iran. 
 
 Personally, I think this is likely becuase the iranians are tired of hearing Bushs spineless and meritless threats and his rediculous talk abotu a reform movement in Iran (the reformist movement in iran has been dead for years, only fools are still holding onto that illusion). 
 
 Any thoughs on how this will affect the current round of hostiliites between the Iranians and the US? Any effect on the EUs dealing with Iran?

Mahmoud Ahmadi-Nejad, a conservative hardliner, was recently elected president of Iran by a wide margin (around 60% IIRC). 
 
 This means thatt he conservatives are now running everthing in Iran. 
 
 Personally, I think this is likely becuase the iranians are tired of hearing Bushs spineless and meritless threats and his rediculous talk abotu a reform movement in Iran (the reformist movement in iran has been dead for years, only fools are still holding onto that illusion). 
 
 Any thoughs on how this will affect the current round of hostiliites between the Iranians and the US? Any effect on the EUs dealing with Iran?

 
 I feel that it will be bad for relations between the EU and Iran. Being a hardliner, and former Revolutionary Guard member ( meaning a strongly religous person) I believe his believes will interfere with diplomatic relations. Sometimes having a person with strong personal morals is impratical for politics and diplomacy.
 
 I understand that he was elected with strong support from the poorer Iranians, who are actually becoming concerned about the corruption and poor economic situation in Iran. The corruption from some of the clerics and generally from the business class who are not following the religous aspects of Islam.

what election?
 
 all that happened was a show (here is our candidate) and tell (he is now the winner).
 
 someone who had single digit independent polls now had 60%.
 yeah, no funny business there.
In Russia they used to give out booze at polling stations. Ah, the good times...
